title: CSC477-Group-4
text:
Preface
This is the Quarto book for Group 4. This group consists of Samuel Zelaya, Diego Mendoza, Janice Oenardi, and Chris Karottukoikal.
Here’s an overview of the topics each of the group members have chosen:

Samuel Zelaya > NASA Earth Data https://www.earthdata.nasa.gov/
Diego Mendoza > US Department of Agriculture Data http://www.nal.usda.gov
Janice Oenardi > Federal Reserve Economic Data https://fred.stlouisfed.org/
Chris Jacob K > NCES Data https://nces.ed.gov/datatools/

In the weekly updates section, you’ll be able to see the weekly updates for each of these projects.

title: 1  Weekly Updates
text:
1.1 Week 1 (August 26 ~ August 30)
No updates yet! Everyone’s started working on their data sets.

title: 1  Weekly Updates
text:
1.1.1 Notes from Chris on Monday (Aug 26)
Our first task is going to be to create a documentation on the data sets that we have chosen. Let’s work on getting information on the data, the formats it’s available in, the data represented, the data points collected, and even the extent of data provided in each of the sets.

1.1.1.1 Chris’ Update

Excel Unit 1 tasks

Worked on the Excel unit with the airquality_datasets.csv file, and followed the suggested steps




Step 1 - Highlighting NA Values using conditional formatting





Step 2 - Filtering out NA values for Ozone and Day columns





Step 3 - Creating a scatter plot of Ozone vs Day



Applied the steps to another dataset, the diamonds_ggplot2.csv set.




Step 1 - Loaded the CSV onto excel and examined the rows and columns


The Diamonds dataset defines the different characteristics of a diamond namely, carat, cut, color, clarity, depth, price, and lengths in the x, y, and z direction The dataset itself did not have any NA values, and hence did not need any additional steps for cleaning the data. An interesting observation to be made was that there are several interesting correlations between the columns that can help us observe some basic trends in the diamond trading business. There were more than 53,000 records collected, and so this dataset is very comprehensive! I planned on using the dataset to compare the cut of a diamond against the price of the diamond, thus showing us the most premium or sought after diamonds and the range at which they are sold. 
Next, I created different charts to visualize the data. I started with the scatter plot.    
Given the size of the dataset, I decided to only use 150 records to determine correlations as an exmaple.
When trying to create more visualizations, I observed that not all charts were capable of visualizing this data, and furthermore, given the size of the dataset, all operations were much slower on the online excel sheet.
I believe the best visualization for such data is the Bar Chart of Price vs Carats, because it captures the inherent reality that more carats means more price.

All in all, it was an interesting start to the class and helped me better understand how visualizations can be achieved on excel.

title: 2  Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.
